articles.headline: Justices Limit Use of ‘Honest Services’ Law Against Fraud
articles.snippet: Ruling for two corporate executives in prison for fraud, the Supreme Court drastically narrowed the scope of a law often used by federal prosecutors in corruption cases.
articles.abstract: Ruling for two corporate executives in prison for fraud, the Supreme Court drastically narrowed the scope of a law often used by federal prosecutors in corruption cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday significantly narrowed the scope of a law often used by federal prosecutors in corruption cases and called into question the fraud convictions of Jeffrey K. Skilling, a former chief executive of Enron, and Conrad M. Black, a newspaper executive convicted of defrauding his media company.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Rolls Back a Law Born of Enron
articles.snippet: The court gave a victory to the mastermind of the Enron fraud and may throw out a reform law inspired by it.
articles.abstract: The court gave a victory to the mastermind of the Enron fraud and may throw out a reform law inspired by it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The timing is exquisite. First the Supreme Court of the United States provided a significant legal victory to the mastermind behind one of the greatest corporate frauds in American history. Next the court may throw out the law that Congress passed to reform corporate America  a law inspired by that very fraud.

articles.headline: On New iPhone, a Mystery of Dropped Calls
articles.snippet: Network connections inexplicably disappeared when iPhone 4 users cradled their phones in a particular way.
articles.abstract: Network connections inexplicably disappeared when iPhone 4 users cradled their phones in a particular way.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  For iPhone owners, it always comes back to the antenna.

articles.headline: A New Plan for Valuing Pensions
articles.snippet: The current standard has come under heavy fire from mainstream economists, who say it makes virtually all government pension benefits look less costly than they really are.
articles.abstract: The current standard has come under heavy fire from mainstream economists, who say it makes virtually all government pension benefits look less costly than they really are.
articles.lead_paragraph: The board that writes accounting rules for states and cities has proposed a new approach for pension disclosures that falls far short of what some financial experts hoped, but which would still force many governments to highlight pension shortfalls they have downplayed.

articles.headline: Pakistan Is Said to Pursue Foothold in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Pakistani officials want to bring the network of Sirajuddin Haqqani, an Al Qaeda ally, into a power-sharing deal.
articles.abstract: Pakistani officials want to bring the network of Sirajuddin Haqqani, an Al Qaeda ally, into a power-sharing deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Jane Perlez, Eric Schmitt and Carlotta Gall.
articles.byline: By JANE PERLEZ, ERIC SCHMITT and CARLOTTA GALL

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Gains in Its Wooing of Chicago
articles.snippet: In an effort to make itself more acceptable to urban areas, Wal-Mart has offered to shrink its stores and maybe even pay its employees more.
articles.abstract: In an effort to make itself more acceptable to urban areas, Wal-Mart has offered to shrink its stores and maybe even pay its employees more.
articles.lead_paragraph: What would it take for urban areas to welcome Wal-Mart?

articles.headline: A Long, Hard Path to the Public
articles.snippet: Many analysts view Higher One’s successful market debut as a sign of a long-awaited thaw in the market for initial public offerings.
articles.abstract: Many analysts view Higher One’s successful market debut as a sign of a long-awaited thaw in the market for initial public offerings.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2000, when three Yale undergraduates founded an online financial services company called Higher One Holdings, they had visions of rapid growth and successively bigger rounds of financing from investors. With any luck, momentum would build toward the ultimate dot-com dream: a stock listing on a major public exchange.

articles.headline: Analysts Question a Threat by Fannie
articles.snippet: Experts wondered what Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance giant, hoped to achieve by announcing it would punish owners who strategically defaulted.
articles.abstract: Experts wondered what Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance giant, hoped to achieve by announcing it would punish owners who strategically defaulted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae’s decision to begin punishing people who walk away from their unpaid mortgages could prove difficult to sell to the public and might be impossible to execute, housing and lending experts said Thursday.

articles.headline: Democrats See Signs of Hope in Job Trends
articles.snippet: There are some glimmers of hope for the Democrats as economic improvement comes to some important battleground areas for the House and the Senate.
articles.abstract: There are some glimmers of hope for the Democrats as economic improvement comes to some important battleground areas for the House and the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: A struggling economy has historically meant trouble for the president’s party in midterm elections. So it comes as no surprise that Democrats are girding for a tough November.

articles.headline: In Deal, New Authority Over Wall Street
articles.snippet: An overhaul of the financial regulatory system will vastly expand governmental authority in a bid to curb what led to the plunge of the world economy in 2008.
articles.abstract: An overhaul of the financial regulatory system will vastly expand governmental authority in a bid to curb what led to the plunge of the world economy in 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  An overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system, reached after an all-night Congressional horse-trading session, will vastly expand the authority of the federal government over Wall Street in a bid to curb the free-wheeling culture that led to the near collapse of the world economy in 2008.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: From Card Fees to Mortgages, a New Day for Consumers
articles.snippet: Provisions in the financial bill will change many ways of doing business.
articles.abstract: Provisions in the financial bill will change many ways of doing business.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
